article.headline: Relocating? Ask these 6 questions to find the place thatâs right for you
article.body: You may have been impressed by a city you visited once on vacation or that you discovered while scrolling through a list of affordable places to live. But if youâre considering a move and looking for a new city to call home, a lot of factors influence your decision. Here are a half dozen questions to answer before landing on your next place to live, and where to gather the information soÂ you can find a city thatâs just right for you.1. âWhatâs the cost of living?â Knowing just how far your hard-earned dollar will go in a new city is a priority when youâre looking to relocate.Â As more companiesÂ âÂ particularly those in tech, finance and insurance âÂ allow their employees to continue working remotely on a full-time basis after COVID-19, more people have the option toÂ move out of big, expensive metro areasÂ and find more affordable places to live. The appeal of affordable small and midsize cities has never been stronger or more attainable;Â imagine working for a Bay Area tech company, but living in a smaller, friendlier city and paying a fraction of Bay Area rent (seriously, donât readÂ these median homeÂ pricesÂ unless youâre sitting down). This trend also allows employers to hire top talent without hefty relocation and cost of living fees. This could bolster the appeal of places likeÂ Tulsa, which has been setting up incentive programs toÂ convince remote workers to move to their citiesÂ through theÂ Tulsa Remote program. Of course, housing affordability is a good metric to begin with, and you can plug U.S. cities into LivabilityâsÂ âFind Your Cityâ toolÂ to easily access data on median home prices, median rent, and a housing affordability ranking. But cost of living isnât just about housing costs. Other considerations include things like retail sales tax rates, parks passes, fishing licenses, parking fees, the price of an average lunch out, and how much it costsÂ to register and insure your car, saysÂ Baron Christopher Hanson, lead consultant and owner ofÂ RedBaronUSA, who has worked as a consultant withÂ chamber of commerce groups. If you travel frequently (in normal times), are flights affordable from your home airport? Do local museums, zoos, and botanical gardens offer free days? How much are bus passes? Visit: Where should I retire? âTailor your list to your own life, family, career and interests,â Hanson says.2. âHow much are property taxes and HOA fees?â While you may have a good idea of what median rent prices or home costs are in an area, go a step further and review property taxes and HOA fees to get a true snapshot of your cost of living.Â To find an areaâs property taxes, you can use anÂ online calculator. HomeownerÂ association fees have been on the rise throughout the country, according to aÂ study from Trulia. Average monthly HOA fees were $250 in 2005 but ballooned to $331 by 2015, which outpaced the growth in housing prices and inflation rates. Metros with the cheapest monthly HOA fees included Nashville, Tennessee ($194); Las Vegas, Nevada ($198); Indianapolis, Indiana ($213); Charlotte, North Carolina ($218) and Warren, Michigan ($218).Â HOA fees can be tricky. They might seem outrageous to former renters or those who lived in a neighborhood that didnât have associations, explains Tracy Jones, a Realtor with Re/Max RMAX, -0.35% Â Oak Crest Realty in Elkhart, Indiana and Sarasota, Florida. âBut these fees might include trash, cable, security, a gym, internet,â she says. âSo, you might actually save money.â The takeaway? Research whatâs included to decide if itâs worth it for you.3. âHow diverse is the economy?â One way to determine how healthy a local economy is, and how it might weather a recession, is to check outÂ the diversity of its industriesÂ and how evenly employment is distributed across these industries and occupations. Economic development offices make information available about key industries and will often have data on the areaâs major employers and how many people each company employs. Labor market analytics firmÂ Emsi has reported on industry diversityÂ and Livability recently shared a list of theÂ 10 Most Diversified Economies in the U.S. Also see: Hereâs why college towns are among the most economically resilient places in the country4. âWhat opportunities are available for young professionals?â When you move to a new city, it helps to have a network that will help set you up for success. Check with the local chamber of commerce to see if thereâs an active young professionals branch.Â Some areas excel when it comes to embracing young professionals. For example, in Chattanooga,Â ChattaNewbiesÂ hosts happy hours to bring young professionals together and hosts events so newcomers can learn the history of Chattanooga and where the city is headed next. Plus,Â ProtÃ©gÃ© ChattanoogaÂ runs a mentoring program for early and midcareer professionals, allowing them to learn from local executives and aÂ Young Professional SummitÂ includes expert-led career sessions.Â In Kentucky, theÂ Northern Kentucky Young ProfessionalsÂ program provides those under the age of 40 with professional development and community involvement opportunities.Â Read: I work in Silicon Valley, but my job is now remote. I can finally live somewhere cheaper. Where should I go? A number of young professional groups have formed throughout Wisconsin, includingÂ Madison Magnet,Â a group that hosts professional development events, organizes volunteer opportunities and holds happy hours and social gatherings.Â Thinking of starting your own business? Check in with the areaâs economic development office, the stateâs small business office or the local chamber to see what kind of incentives and grants are available for entrepreneurs.5. âHow easy is it to get around?â Getting around town with ease makes everyday life more enjoyable. You can find out just how walkable a city or neighborhood is by plugging it intoÂ Walk Score, which layers in factors like whether thereâsÂ âa centerâ like a main street or public space, if there are parks and public spaces to gather, if there are streets designed for bicyclists and pedestrians as well as transit and if thereâs affordable housing located near businesses. (LivabilityâsÂ Top 100 Best Places to Live listÂ also factors in walk score and accessibility.) Donât miss: Rethinking big city life? Here are 8 smaller places that still have the urban perks As for transportation, in addition to checking for existing transit lines, city shuttles and bus routes, pay attention to what investments a city is making in its infrastructure by checking out City Council or transportation authority announcements and meeting minutes. Placerville, Calif., is considered very walkable. iStock And if standstill traffic is a deal breaker for you, consider one of theseÂ 10 great cities that have little to no traffic.6. âWhatÂ outdoor recreation is available, and how easy is it to access?â As weâve all been cooped up in COVID-19 quarantine and lost access to many of our favorite Hocking Hills State Forest, Ohio. iStock indoor gathering places, weâve realized just how important it is to have access to the great outdoors. If youâre making a move, itâs important to ask what types of amenitiesÂ âÂ mountains, rivers, lakes,Â large public parksÂ â are in your greater backyard, and what kind of access will you have to them.Â Read: Weâre looking for a place thatâs not too hot, not too cold, and accepting of different races â where should we retire? Information about how many miles of trails and the number of public parks and golf courses are often made available by communities.Â ButÂ some cities have particularly interesting outdoor amenities. Take for instanceÂ Castle Rock, ColoradoâsÂ âChallenge Hill,â which is a heart-pumping 200-step incline that shows off sweeping views of Pikes Peak and the Front Range. Or, inÂ Prattville, Alabama, a wilderness park in the city has a trail shaded by 60-footÂ bamboo trees. Yes, please!
